Award.AwardTitle: Catalyzing New International Collaboration Between Stevens Institute and Eindhoven University: Catalytic Gold and Silver Nanoparticles for Green Chemistry and Sustainability
Award.AbstractNarration:
Commercial production of many large scale oxygen-containing commodity chemicals currently relies on multi-stage, energy inefficient processes with undesirable byproducts. The development of new green and energy efficient oxidation technologies to replace such processes is essential for sustainable chemical production. This project will catalyze a new collaboration between researchers at Stevens Institute of Technology and Eindhoven University in the Netherlands to advance the molecular-level understanding of how oxygen interacts with gold and silver nanoparticles for green chemistry and sustainability in the chemical industry. The collaboration brings together the novel experimental and computational methodologies at Stevens with unique testing capabilities at Eindhoven. The project activities will entail (a) preparation of catalytic materials with a controlled size of gold and silver nanoparticles, (b) utilization of a specially developed photonic crystal fiber with immobilized gold and silver nanoparticles for dramatically improved detection sensitivities of molecules on surfaces, (c) testing of chemical reactions and spectroscopic studies under reaction conditions, and (d) surface modeling of silver and gold nanoparticles with quantum-chemical calculations.

This international project will establish the basis for the transformative development of new efficient and environmentally friendly technologies to insure sustainability of chemical production. U.S. students will spend an extended period of time at the collaborating laboratories in the Netherlands, working on closer integration between experimental and computational methods. The researchers will also be engaged in undergraduate and K-12 educational outreach programs at Stevens. For example, teaching modules on metal nanoparticles for green chemistry and sustainability will be used in a summer camp for more than 200 high school students from across the U.S.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Commercial production of many large scale oxygen-containing commodity chemicals currently relies on multi-stage energy inefficient processes with undesirable byproducts. Development of new green and energy efficient oxidation technologies to replace such processes is urgent and essential for sustainability of chemical production. Gold and silver nanoparticles have been shown to be highly promising catalysts that can directly use benign and readily available gas-phase oxygen. It has also been demonstrated that desirable chemicals can be produced in a single efficient step. In these new chemical reactions, in contrast to existing commercial technologies, water is the only byproduct. Commercialization of new chemistries and improvements in current technologies, however, are severely hindered by a lack of fundamental understanding of how oxygen interacts with gold and silver nanoparticles. This lack of understanding is mainly due to two factors. Firstly, chemical properties of gold and silver nanoparticles change dramatically as the size of these particles increases. As a result, it is challenging to characterize materials with such nanoparticles because the dependence of chemical properties on the size of nanoparticles is not well understood. Secondly, the concentration of chemically active sites on gold and silver nanoparticles is usually so low that they cannot be reliably characterized with traditional methods. Furthermore, there is a lack of integration between experimental and theoretical studies.

     The goal of this project was to advance molecular-level understanding of how oxygen interacts with gold and silver nanoparticles for green chemistry and sustainability in the chemical industry through catalyzing a new collaboration between Stevens Institute of Technology in the U.S. with Eindhoven University in the Netherlands. The project allowed the researchers to synergistically combine the novel experimental and computational methodologies at Stevens Institute with unique testing capabilities at Eindhoven University. During the project, the following activities were undertaken: (a) preparation of new catalytic materials with a controlled size of gold and silver nanoparticles, (b) utilization of a specially developed photonic crystal fiber with immobilized gold and silver nanoparticles for dramatically improved detection sensitivities of molecules on surfaces, (c) testing of chemical reactions with synthesized catalytic metal nanoparticles, and (d) surface modeling of silver and gold nanoparticles with quantum-chemical calculations.

     This project will help to establish the basis for transformative development of new efficient and environmentally friendly technologies to ensure sustainability of chemical production. The research findings are readily extendable from gold and silver to other metal nanoparticles. Participating graduate students were engaged in regular and frequent communications with their counterparts abroad and spent extended time at the collaborating laboratories in the Netherlands with the emphasis on learning the culture, research approaches and, especially, on close integration between experimental and computational methods. The investigators and participating students were engaged in several undergraduate and K-12 educational outreach programs. As an example, teaching modules on metal nanoparticles for green chemistry and sustainability were used in a summer camp, where 300 high school students from across the U.S. live in 2-week sessions on campus of Stevens Institute of Technology and learn about research activities at the university.
